text: Ah, it’s Fall. Not in a cozy, peaceful way. In that slush miserable Midwest way. Strong winds bend the trees of Lakeshore Drive. Grey rain drips from the Magnificent Mil storefronts to the street signs of the suburbs.
The lights turn on at the Portokalos house.

A large old black Cadillac backs down the driveway of the Corinthian-columned home. It drives at a wrong angle. Stops. Drives forward, corrects. Backs out again. Correct again. Backs out. The car drives ten feet and stops at the very next home. SFX: HONKING. That house door opens.

CLOSE-UP: A smudged “HAPPINESS IS BEING GREEK” Greek flag cover on an OPA! license plate. PAN UP.... INT. GUS’S CADILLAC/MILLER HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS SFX: Car door closing. Through the windshield, in the passenger seat, TOULA PORTOKALOS, 40's, is burrowed in a scarf, her glasses fog with every breath. (CONTINUED)

You better get married, you're starting to look old. Startled, Toula looks up, realizes her dad is not talking her. In fact, he is looking in the rear-view mirror, at t back seat. At Toula’s daughter.

Pappou!! Gus shrugs, puts the car in gear. Toula, not looking together this morning, or ever, shakes her head.
Well, that’s a family tradition. My dad used to say that to me and now he just said it to my daughter. She’s 17.

Families that are close like mine, we make it through bad economies, wars and sickness because we stick together... Toula goes to a drawer, finds a strip of empty disposable contact lenses. She remembers something, and rummages to find a pair of glasses. They’re ugly and they were once hers. She puts them on. Toula looks as downcast and frumpy as she once did.
.-.- but some of us just get stuck. Toula looks out the window. Cars and PEOPLE pass her by. day is as bleak as her mood.

I can’t take that everyone is always in my business! Give me some air. I’m not a kid, I can be late to a class, there won’t be a spasmodic catastrophic ripple in the space-time continuum. And yes, four of those words are Greek. Paris storms away, Ian looks worn out.

I don’t know, do I have to do everything? Aunt Voula pulls a sexy red nightgown from the bag. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) And for afterward, this will help you sleep better. Toula looks at the nightgown, groans. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Satin is slippery, like an eel in --
Thea, please! That’s the last thing I can think about. I need a shower and wrinkle cream -- Aunt Voula cups Toula’s face, looks her over.

Wrinkles? No, no, wrinkles. Greek don’t creak. Aunt Voula points to the nightgown. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Anyway, you know what Taki likes in bed? Toula covers her ears, makes noises to drown out Aunt Vou AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Confidence! That’s sexy. Okay, I’m done. Toula uncovers her ears. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) And, dress up like a hotel maid, men love morning room service, sunny side up! Toula claps her hands.
Good talk!
Go on your date, don’t worry about anything. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Mana-Yiayia and I will stay with Paris. I’11 talk to her, scare her out of moving away from her family. (laughs) I’m kidding. But not really. Anyway, have fun. Laugh, flirt. One rule: don’t fight, which means don’t talk about your daughter. Remember, you were a girlfriend before you were a mother. Toula smiles, doesn’t know what to say. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) You’re welcome. Aunt Voula waves her hand from Toula’s eyebrows to toes. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Shave everything.

Ian sits in a booth, DRESSED AND GROOMED LIKE HE’S HAD A MAKEOVER, looking great, and a bit nervous. Toula, also dressed up, hair blown out, makeup on, walks up. They see each other. A moment. It’s nice. Ian stands to pull her chair out.
Quick. Sit down before my wife gets here. Toula laughs. They admiringly look at each other.
You're... clean.
Thank you.
Your hair....
I washed it.
You look pretty. (CONTINUED)
Four hours, five hundred dollars.
How much?!
You look so handsome!
Yeah? Thanks. Aunt Voula called me and said, “you used to be handsome, get it together.” I got my nose hairs trimmed. Toula wryly smiles at that.
Ah, who says there’s no romance after marriage? Ian leans in.
Me.
Me, too. Ian takes her hand.
Let’s work on it. Toula smiles softly.
Okay. They open their menus.
Don’t have garlic. You might get lucky tonight. Toula blushes and laughs. A WAITER comes by.
Would you like something to drink?
Yes!! (CONTINUED)
Ian points to a wine on the list. 37 The Waiter goes. They look around. Turn back, smile shyly
Do you think Paris will go toa college out of state? Toula remembers what Aunt Voula said.
Thea Voula suggested we don’t talk about Paris. How was your day?
Um, good. What’d you do?
Worked, found out my parents aren’t married. You?
Your parents are swingers. The Waiter pours their wine. They drink. Smile awkwardly.
So wait, why can’t we talk about Paris?
Right? I have to!
Okay, how do we keep her from moving away for college?
We could act like it’s okay with us.
Reverse psychology. Good. How about a letter? Dear Admissions Board: I sure hope you accept my daughter and her twelve piece drum kit.
Add in, “do you have a Student Lounge where she can sell pot?” Toula laughs, Ian laughs. They lock eyes. (CONTINUED)
Toula gets emotional.
I don’t know what I’1l do if she goes... Ian takes her hand.
C’mon, hon. It’s our one night out in forever. Toula fights to not cry. Ian picks up a menu.
It‘ll be okay. Toula sadly nods.
The radio PLAYS. Ian drives as Toula looks out the window It’s tense; their date didn’t go well. Ian sighs.
This is why Aunt Voula said don’t talk about Paris.
But once you’re a parent, what else do you want to talk about?
I don’t know.
Thea Voula said to remember I was a girlfriend before I was a mother. Ian slowly smiles a bit at that.
Yeah, you were my girlfriend. Now Toula slowly smiles a bit. Ian turns the corner. They're on their street. Ian points to the Portokalos fam home in the distance. (CONTINUED)
Remember when we were dating, how you wouldn't let me drop you off in front in case your parents saw me?
No, I didn’t want you to see the house.
How could I miss it? Ian pulls over and parks.
We used to park right here. It’s dark. And quiet. Ian looks out the windshield.
I remember those good night kisses. Toula looks at him.
You do, huh? Ian leans in.
Yes. They kiss. It’s nice. It keeps going. And going. Really going. The MUSIC swells. And then -- a LIGHT shines into the car.
What are you doing? Toula and Ian cover themselves, shield their eyes. Gus shines a flashlight into the car.
Nothing, nothing, we're going.
Everything's okay. (CONTINUED)
Ian struggles to dress himself, Gus realizes what's happening.
You don’t have a house to do that?! Just then, Paris, Aunt Voula and Maria, walking the old L Socrates, round the corner. They see Gus.
Gus, what’s wrong? Aunt Voula and Maria run up, realize it’s Toula and Ian, to push Gus’s flashlight away. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Gus! Paris realizes it’s her parents.
(nuh-uh) Perfect.
Parents deserve a sex life.
Said no one, ever.
We're just talking. By the way Paris, we think you should go to college out of state. Toula nods her head as hard as she can.
What is that, reverse psychology?
That never works.
That never works.
That never works. The nosy/cranky neighbor Mrs. White, walking her dog, see the commotion. (CONTINUED)
What’s going on, I’m calling the cops.
No, it’s okay, Mrs. White, everything is okay. Socrates starts barking at Mrs. White.
Stop that, quiet!
He doesn’t speak English. (in soothing Greek to the dog, subtitled) Bite her tomorrow. The Portokalos dog immediately sits. Mrs. White suspiciously looks at them all as she leaves.
I have pepper spray. Gus turns back to Ian.
Ian Miller, in the street?! It’s not decent!! Maria turns on Gus, furious.
What’s the problem? At least they're married.
Maria....
Don’t Maria me. We’re not married. Paris’s jaw drops. MARIA (CONT’D) You want decency? Tonight, you sleep in another room. Maria takes the dog toward the house. (CONTINUED)
Fine!
No fine! Neighborhood lights go on. Gus follows Maria in. Aunt Voula leads Paris to the Miller house.
Uh, can I just ask....
Yes dear, your grandparents are living in sin. Your Pappou won't propose-—
I don’t get why Yiayia needs that--
Because you’re not a woman who has lived with Pappou for 50 years. SFX: A door slams inside the Portokalos house. Inside the car, Ian and Toula look at each other.
I have to fix this. Smiling, Ian moves in.
Right, right. Anyway, where were we? Toula pushes him away, laughs.
We can’t.... They go back to making out. From the dark Miller yard, Mana-Yiayia runs by, wearing t red nightgown.
Gus sulks. A PHYSICAL THERAPIST attaches weights to Gus’s ankles.
You're late today.
(mumbles ) My wife wouldn’t drive me.
Pardon?
Nothing.
Lift these, I'll be back. Gus lifts them to impress her. As soon as she’s out of sight, Gus and the OTHER MEN stop working. A swarthy man, KAVEH, 70's, sits on the table beside Gus.
You Greek?
Iranian.
So, Persian? Kaveh nods.
In 334 BC, Alexander the Great conquered the Persian Army and occupied the east. You are so Greek, we're probably related. Insulted, Kaveh puffs up.
We had civilizations in Persia 3000 years before you Greeks discovered rocks. Gus is stunned. (CONTINUED)
The Greeks gave the world philosophy, democracy--
In 2500 BC, we already had instruments that measured weight and money! A Chinese man, PIM, 70's, chimes in.
The Chinese gave the world paper and tea and medicine! Another man, BAIRD, 70'S, chimes in with a Scottish accen
Without Scotland’s Alexander Fleming, the world wouldn’t have penicillin!
Soon I’m going to have proof that I am a direct descendant of Alexander the Great! The others now laugh HARD at Gus. The Physical Therapist comes back, they lift their leg weights. Gus sulks.
INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY From the counter, Toula watches as Gus still sulks in his corner booth. Uncle Taki listens. Gus looks
I sleep with the dog. She won’t give me my pills in the morning, she won’t clean --
Anarchy. over at a table near the counter: Maria whispers with Aunt Voula. (CONTINUED)
Why can’t he just propose?!
Because he’s stubborn! Aunt Voula looks back, sees Gus and Uncle Taki looking at them.

He’s looking, act like you’re having fun. 1-2-3, now. Maria and Aunt Voula throw their heads back, fake-laugh. Nick, Nikki and Angelo watch and shake their heads. Toula brightens as she sees Ian come in, with Paris close behind.

Reporting for my garlic bread shift, woo hoo, it’s so fun, kill me. So many other things I could be doing in my Senior year-- Toula hands the bowl she’s been eating from to Paris, who takes it, eats and trudges away.
Like thinking about Prom....
(mouth full) Nah, I’m not going to that. Paris sits near Nick and Angelo, who dip their spoons int her bowl. Toula hands a coffee to Ian.
Did you check the mail?
Nothing from colleges yet.... Toula is worried. Ian gently puts a strand of hair behind Toula’s ear. That makes her breath catch.
Hey, remember when you asked me on a dinner date? (CONTINUED)
(smiling) Kinda.
How about another date, tonight?
How about yeah. Ian leans in further.
(suggestively) I cleaned the car.
Ooh... The door opens again -- It’s George, the attractive newscaster they met at church
Hi! The family is excited to see George again.
Gus sees it’s George and perks up.
My wife and son are in the car, is this a good time for a visit?
Yes!! George ducks out. Gus claps his hands to Uncle Taki.

He has a son for Paris. Did you see the hair on that Greek god?! I’m going to fix everything, Paris will stay in Chicago, and then-- (full of himself now) -- that woman can propose to me! Uncle Taki grins as Gus starts to slide out of the booth. Gus walks to the front, waving over Paris. (CONTINUED)
Paris, wipe your face. Everyone come, I have a surprise. Uncle Taki, Nick, Nikki and Angelo quickly join. Suddenly, Toula gets it.
Oh! No no. It’s a set-up. Before Paris can protest:
Every Greek girl should have a Greek boyfriend and I found you one! Toula sees Maria and Voula stand and join, so she and Ian quickly head over, resulting in an anticipatory family gr behind Paris.
Hello! Anna and George come in with their son Theodore. He’s sev A pause. Each family member has a different expression. Paris is delighted with how uncomfortable her family is.
Hey buddy, we’re getting married! Everyone is confused.
You said you had a son for our granddaughter--
No, he didn’t! You don’t listen! Anna and George understand, and laugh it off. Paris gestures to Theodore to follow her.
C’mon, you can help me butter garlic bread. Theodore winks at his dad (who winks back) and heads off Paris. (CONTINUED)
Paris gives Toula and Ian the stink-eye as she passes the they can’t win. Gus steps in front of Maria, to gesture to the nearest ta
Anyway, welcome to my restaurant! Maria looks sharply to Gus as George and Anna sit.
Our restaurant! Anna, George and CUSTOMERS look up. Gus tight-smiles back
It’s in my name. Which makes you my employee.
Then I want back pay for 50 years of overtime. Gus and Maria glare at each other. TIan leans in to Toula
Let's go.
What? We can’t leave now- Trying to distract them from the argument, Aunt Voula lea in to Anna and George.
All my life, I wanted to be a newscaster, but I have a dry mouth. When I went through puberty, my tongue swelled up like a tree root. It’s still puffy, look --
I don’t want to. Aunt Voula holds her mouth open. Anna and George peer in.
That’s a big tongue. Toula doesn’t see exasperated Ian leaving. Gus snaps his fingers at Maria. (CONTINUED)
Employee! Bring menus.

Get them yourself! The others are shocked and uneasy. MARIA (CONT’D) (sarcastic) Oh no, I was rude to the boss, I hope I don’t get fired! Maria storms off and slams the door. Toula looks queasy. Then sees Ian is gone.
Establishing.
Maria! Where are you?
Gus limps in, stares at the washer. His clothes are piled high in a basket, with a note: “Your employee is on strik
INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - EVENING The restaurant is empty. Toula gathers her things, checks her cell -- no messages -- makes a call.
Leave a message.
Me again. Um. My dad went home -- his hip, you know -- so I had to... ah, you don’t want to hear... okay, I’m on my way. (CONTINUED)
Toula sighs, turns off the lights.
Toula drives, she’s tired, and worried about Ian.
Toula walks from the car into the house.

Toula is relieved to find Ian sleeping. As he snores, Tou smiles to herself, leans close to kiss him. The house phone rings. Ian opens his eyes, Toula is way too close. He screams. S screams. They scramble for the phone.
Hello? Hi Maria. He looks at Toula.
Yes. Ian hangs up.
Your dad-- Toula grabs her throat.
He’s okay. He’s stuck in the bathtub. Your mom can’t lift him.
OVERHEAD SHOT: Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni, in various states of undress, run from separate houses and u the Portokalos family driveway.
Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run up.
Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run in: Maria points, Nick runs past her and into the bathroom.
What’s up, Dad?
Hello Nicko! Nick immediately comes out, pale.
Ma, you couldn’t put some clothes on him?
If I could, I wouldn’t need you.
What happened?
Did he fall?
No, it’s that hip. It’s locked. Gus yells from the bathroom.
I’m fine! Maria back. (CONTINUED)
No fine! Do your physical therapy like the rest of us.
How long has he been in that tub? Maria shrugs.
A few hours. He wouldn’t let me call you. So, I let the water go cold. The sleeping dog at her feet, in the armchair, Mana-Yiayi does embroidery and laughs at the dilemma.
Maria, will you please drain the tub--
-- and put a towel over him? Maria nods and goes into the bathroom.
(to Toula) Thank you.
Yeah, you can’t unsee that.
What’s going on?
Just be quiet. As Maria argues with Gus, the men look at each other.
Do we call an ambulance? Toula and Nick shake their heads at Ian.
It’ll make him feel old.
He’d never forgive you. (CONTINUED)
Me?
Well, you’d call. And we’d have to tell him you called.
C'mon, how do we do this?
When I was in the kitchen, to season a roast, we had to get our hands under it and turn it over. Toula realizes what he is suggesting and grimaces.
Sure, I flipped a dead body once -- Ian opens drawers, cupboards.
Surely the man has a pair of shorts! Maria comes out, shuts the door.
Okay, I put a towel over his private area --
A big one. Maria rolls her eyes.
Yes, yes Gus, a big one. She shakes her head to everyone. Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni look at each other -- they h to do this.
So, what’s our plan again?
We roll him over -- (CONTINUED)
-- then he’s on his hands and knees and up.
That will work. The men nod, head toward the bathroom with Ian trailing.
Wait, how would that work? Nick ignores Ian, turns back and looks at the other men.
Ready?
Nuh uh./No./God no. Nick opens the door and they head in.
Gus sits in the tub. Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run in:
Why are your eyes closed?
RED and BLUE LIGHTS illuminate houses. An AMBULANCE and a FIRE TRUCK are in front of the Portokalos family home.

head_text.subj: AT THE BASE OF THE DRIVEWAY/ON THE SIDEWALK

text: SEVERAL NEIGHBORS watch the drama. The cranky neighbor, M White, walks up, sees the yellow tape.
I always knew there’d be a murder here. Mike pulls up in his squad car, goes into the house.
(CONTINUED)
Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni sit on the ambulance back fender. They shudder, huddled in blankets, all being trea for cuts, bruises and sprains. Aunt Voula appears with a bottle of Metaxa.

This will take away your pain. Twice I drank it and gave birth without drugs. Aunt Voula leans in to the AMBULANCE ATTENDANT: AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) One of my ovaries never put out an egg. Not one. The other one would spit out two a month. I could feel it, right here. Ping, ping. But the left ovary? Nothing. It was closed, like a stuck zipper.... Toula rubs Ian’s shoulders.
You okay? Ian blinks and opens his eyes.
I still see it. They share the bottle, sipping Metaxa.
Does this count as a date? Ian gives her a wry smile, but shakes his head, no. Suddenly, Toula holds her arms out to him.
I’m sorry -- Then--
Toula!
Coming! Toula and Ian sigh and she runs toward the house. (CONTINUED)
As she passes, Toula notices the neighbors, including Mar and Edie, the Volunteer Committee moms, watching it all.
Here comes a stretcher.
Ah. I’m sure the grandma finally went.
What was she, a hundred and twenty?
Must have slept in pickle juice. Mrs. White turns, sees Mana-Yiayia right beside her and j as if she’s seen a ghost. Mana-Yiayia doesn’t bat an eye.
Gus is wheeled out to the ambulance in the driveway.
I’m fine! Maria follows.
No fine! Toula go to the hospital.
You're not coming?!
No. Because guess why? Family members only. That means children and wife. If you had one! The Neighbors murmur at this salacious morsel. Marge and Edie look at each other with glee.
What? Edie giggles. The ATTENDANTS push Gus’s stretcher down the driveway. Gus’s POV: Maria gets smaller and smaller. And smaller. Suddenly, Gus sits up and cries out. (CONTINUED)
Maria, please, will you marry me?! The entire FAMILY and NEIGHBORHOOD wait. Maria pauses, then satisfied, nods once.
Yes, okay, I’ll marry you. Toula, take me to the hospital.
I’ll get my car. Toula heads down the driveway, and sees the neighbors on sidewalk, whispering.
«+. such a weird family.
Odd people. Toula shakes her head but ignores them. Toula now sees: Paris is in the Miller driveway... she he Angry, Toula turns back to the neighbors.
What? Marge and Edie look up, caught, but not chagrined.
You mean pardon?

No, I mean, what. As in what is wrong with you? You’re standing on our lawn making fun of my family? Oh we're so weird, oh we smell like burnt oregano and feta cheese. I got it. But that’s my dad going into that ambulance, my dad -- Toula fights back tears. Paris steps forward, puts her ar around her mom.
Good night everyone. The Neighbors quickly disperse. (CONTINUED)
Paris slowly walks her mom to their driveway.
I‘1l come to the hospital too. Toula puts a hand on her daughter.
The black Cadillac backs out of the Portokalos driveway, stops at the Miller home. Toula and Paris hurry out.

I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/NICK’S HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS Maria is driving, tired and still mad. Toula rubs her eye There’s a knock on Maria’s window: it’s Marge and Edie. Toula looks back at Paris. Maria opens the window.
Good morning.
How’s your husband?
He’ll live. So I can kill him. Toula is surprised at the women’s empathy. Maria drives.
What was that?
Basically Mom told them to suck it. Toula realizes she did.
Good. Paris, you come from a long line of strong women.
Which means, you can choose your own seven-year-old boyfriend. (CONTINUED)
Toula sees that for the first time in a long time, Paris smiles at something she said.
So, Yiayia, are you and Pappou really going to get married now? Now Maria grins.
Yes, and this time, I’m doing it right!
A GREEK SINGER sings WHITE WEDDING over.... A MONTAGE!

Holding out her brochure, a CHIC WEDDING PLANNER walks in smiling. Then she glares at: PULL BACK: Maria, Aunt Voula and Athena going through the racks of creamy, dreamy dresses. In the front window Mana-Yiayia poses in a wedding dress.
The Wedding Planner presents cream and white flowers. Tou and Nikki see Maria reach for her choice - a giant bouque orange birds of paradise.
The Wedding Planner shows a demure cake and is shocked wh Maria, Athena and Nikki love a garish cake.
Maria excitedly points to a sample of a Bride and a Groom faces floating in two roses. The Wedding Planner face pal herself.

The Wedding Planner shows an elegant black limousine. She turns to find Maria loving a GIANT PINK LIMO VAN. Inside car, Athena and Nikki have powdered sugar under their nos as they eat kourambiedes. Maria hands her phone to the Wedding Planner.
Take a picture.
One, two, three, pull! Maria and Aunt Voula pull each other’s neck skin. FLASH.
IT’S ALMOST SPRING. Ian walks from his car to the house mailbox.
Toula takes a roast chicken from the oven. Ian comes in - bit shaken -- with mail from VARIOUS COLLEGES.
Paris? Paris comes in, sees the look on their faces.
You open them. Ian tears envelopes, reads the letters, looks up, emotion (CONTINUED)
Toula Paris She's Paris Toula
Well, it looks like a choice between Northwestern... (pointedly) .+. right here in Chicago. And uh, NYU in New York. and Ian grab Paris into a three-way hug.
We are so proud of you!
So proud! And, uh... the question is, where do you want to go to college? is proud of herself. Her expression turns fearful. not ready to go away. She thinks, then looks up.
I'll stay here in Chicago.
(faux casual) Okay, if that’s what you want. is relieved. They hug again. Behind Paris’s head, and Ian celebrate.
INT. DANCING ZORBA’S OFFICE - DAY, LATER Toula runs in.
Dad, did you hear the news, Paris is staying!
She found a boyfriend?
Dad--
Very good news, Toula!
Yup! (CONTINUED)
62 Gus shows a certified mail receipt to: Find Your Ancestry Gus Gus Gus Gus hip
Oh, look what I mailed today.
You completed the application!
By myself. It was hard to remember every name and date--
(gently) You could have called Theo Panos in Greece. grumbles.
So my brother can tell me what I’m doing is stupid. is standing without a cane. It rests on the wall. snorts.
Your physical therapy is working.
It’s not that therapy. I fixed it myself. pulls out a bottle of Windex, lifts his shirt, sprays his area, stretches, grins at Toula.
You're happy the wedding is on, huh?
But Toula, I can’t afford the wedding your mother wants! That’s not news to Toula, she nods.
We could give you money.
No! You need it for college. (CONTINUED)
Gus rubs his chest from the anxiety.

I can’t sleep without your mother snoring! (gets serious) You're married, you know what it’s like to have that person there, right beside you. In every way. You walk through your life, seeing your shadow as two people. You know you can reach out in the night and that person is there. And then they’re not... because they make you stay on the couch until a Priest says it’s okay!
At the kitchen table, Paris and Mana-Yiayia dip koulouria into milk.
Mana-Yiayia, I’m going to stay home for college. Mana-Yiayia smiles. They eat.
That's good, right? It’s what I want. Mana-Yiayia stops chewing, looks at Paris.
But is not. Mana-Yiayia smiles gently. SFX: a front door slams. Paris and Mana-Yiayia look up: Maria comes in, distraught.
The Wedding Planner fired me!
Toula paces. Ian rushes in from work.
So now they’re not getting married?!
I have to fix this. Ian takes a moment. Then --
When do you think you can fix us? Toula looks up quickly.
What do you mean?
You're always running in and out of here, cooking something, volunteering somewhere. It’s like you avoid being alone with me--
But you just explained why I’m not here.
Look, it’s my fault too; we're busy. But Toula, we’ve been trying to have a date, just another dinner alone. And it’s impossible. Your family pulls at you--
That’s what family does--
No, that’s what your family does, my family doesn’t pull me.
Well, maybe they do but you don’t notice-- Toula lays her head on Ian’s chest. (CONTINUED)
Please. Help me get my parents married. They hold each other. It’s sweet.
All right. Who can we ask? They look at each other. And grin.
Toula opens the front door and Aunt Voula enters.
I’m here! Toula starts to shut the door, but it opens. The ENTIRE FAMILY (except Maria and Gus) comes thundering
You called the family?!
Of course. Ian is surprised as RODNEY AND HARRIET, 70's, arrive. AUNT FREIDA, 60’s, announces in her always-loud voice.
Rodney and Harry are here!
Hey, Mom and Dad.
Yiasas, Yiasas everyone!
You got any of that moussaka?
The family are squashed on the couch, chairs, etc. (CONTINUED)
Tell your problem.
Uh, okay...
Toula’s parents are not married. No one blinks.
Oh, you all know?
Please. Aunt Freida shrugs.
Telephone, telegram, tell-a-Greek.
The wedding planner quit! No one blinks again.
You know that too?
What are you, new? JENNIE, 30's, nods.
Of course we know.
We know everything.
I tweeted it.
Aunt Voula we were hoping you could talk to Maria?
Convince her to just go to the church and get it done. 66 (CONTINUED)
The AUNTS Ian and Toula look at each other. (2)
Please. and UNCLES look at each other.
Why?
Because my dad will lose it.
No, why convince them to just “get it done”?
Look, weddings are expensive--
Very.
But what was with hiring a wedding planner?
I don’t know.
Yeah, we've all had weddings --
Except Angelo--
We're not talking about me! Nikki jumps in. 67 Aunt Voula raises an eyebrow to Nikki: leave it alone.
I’m sayin’ -- you don’t need a caterer.
We all cook.
Some of us better than others.
Don’t start-- (CONTINUED)
Your diples are dry, accept it. Marianthi turns to her husband.
Mike, can you taser her?
Only once per relative, you know my rule.
We'll have the reception at their house!
I’1l do the hair!
Angelo can get Maria a dress!
Yeah! My business partner was in a band, there were tuxedos --
I can do an emailed invitation!
I'll design it with you! Nick and Paris high five. Toula smiles at Paris.
Rodney, don’t you have a client who owns flower shops?
No. Oh, wait, let me think!
I’m sure you told me, flowers!
Oh yes, funeral homes!
Perfect! Okay, what else?
You all want to do this? (CONTINUED)
Of course./Yes!/You bet. Paris sees her mom is touched.
Thank you! Maybe everyone could pick a category: food, glassware-- Aunt Voula interrupts.
The wedding is on! Pick a category and report to me. I’m in charge! 69 Everyone immediately breaks into groups, talks LOUD.
Actually Thea, you’re not--
Yes, it’s best--
I don’t--
It’s what everyone wants, dear. Ian nudges Toula.
Okay.

On this beautiful May day, in slo-mo, a la The Right Stuf Maria and Gus are beaming as they, and the FAMILY power w They are of course led by Aunt Voula, holding her iPad hi showing the Walking App step-count to all behind her. Toula, Ian and the FAMILY walk and animatedly plan the wedding by sharing lists, pictures of flowers and cakes.
Paris sits on the grass, eats lunch. She watches Bennett leaning against a tree. But Bennett is watching cool girl, Tiahn, as she unwraps sandwich. Suddenly, he walks up to her --
